data.title: A Gothic-style gem
data.text:
Great architecture. I love all the details on the outside.
I would give this building 5 stars, but you can't even go in the lobby to see all the details so one star taken off for that.

data.title: A fascinating informative and delightful presentation.
data.text: Anthony Robbins celebrated this iconic building with his vast knowledge of architecture, art and history..  If you have even the smallest interest in history and architecture you will be glad you took this tour.  We took the 90 minute tour.  We learned not only the particulars of the building construction but we went up the street to see other buildings for comparison of their design.  We learned of the uniqueness of the building and the personalities of the major players as  they fit into history.   Mr Robbins had an engaging repartee which made the tour especially enjoyable.

data.title: Terrific tour
data.text: Fascinating stories and amazing building. Loved every minute of our 90 minute tour. Our guide Lisa was great, so knowledgeable and passionate about the subject matter. Not a mainstream tourist attraction - my husband and I loved it!

data.title: What a gorgeous building!
data.text: I took the hour long tour on a whim. It was wonderful. Nina was so knowledgeable and patient. My fellow tourers were an interesting mix who asked fun, intelligent questions. The building is just gorgeous, and full of whimsical, beautiful details. I really, really enjoyed this adventure!

data.title: Guided Tour of the Woolworth Lobby
data.text: The building is closed to pedestrians but a tour of the lobby is available. The tours are 30, 60 or 90 minutes in length and are given by a historian who's doing research about the building. The lobby is incredible to see and the tour is well worth the cost.

data.title: Woolworth 1 hour tour
data.text: This was an excellent tour and made all the better by insightful knowledge of the guide. It is not exciting but full of fascinating history. The architecture is magnificent. It is a shame not to go up much of the tower but that is not promised. We had the benefit of a group of only 3 and my wife who is an architect loved it.

data.title: If you want an interesting hour
data.text: Would encourage people to arrange a visit to this building very informative guide and extremely interesting, worth every penny.

data.title: Tour of Woolworth Building well worthwhile
data.text: We are native New Yorkers and were always curious about the history of this famous skyscraper.  We signed up for the 90 minute tour which was very worthwhile, educational and the guide (Bob Gelber) was extremely knowledgeable.  We learned so much about the 5&10 cent magnate, his architect, the local area and other fascinating tidbits.  Highly recommend Woolworth tours

data.title: Want to see the top of cooper clean
data.text: There are doing brick work on building on the upper part of the building and not the top and the building right next to the world trade building and once there finish the work on the building it stand out as beautiful as it is a great land mark

data.title: Worth every penny
data.text: If you like early 20th cent.architecture and esthetics, this place is exhilarating. One of a few examples of that style in New York City.

data.title: A Fantastic Tour for Residents and Tourists Alike!
data.text: I live in the city and booked this tour with another friend, because we love historical architecture, and we were so blown away! Our guide (a historian of the Woolworth Building) was very knowledgeable about every facet of Frank Woolworth and the building that bears his name, and everything she said was fascinating. We did the 90 minute tour, which is what I would recommend. You will not be bored, and you will learn so much about this gorgeous building with an amazing history. Especially highly recommended for people with a keen interest in NYC history and fans of architecture.

user_location.name: New York, New York, United States

data.title: Notvjust for tourist
data.text:
Great tour and great tour guide. I grew up within walking distance of the Woolworth Building but know
seeing It from the inside out makes me appreciate it even more.

data.title: Fav downtown building
data.text: This is an iconic building in the Financial District, often called FiDi by realtors.  Once the Woolworth Building was the tallest building in the world, from 1913 until 1930.  It is a Neo-Gothic building based on the European Gothic Church design. In part, the design suggests that this building is the cathedral of commerce. Right now, the upper floors are being turned into luxury condos by a local developer. The lobby is stunning.

data.title: Inside look at an amazing building
data.text: If you are interested in architecture, this is a wonderful tour.  I took the 60 min version (they offer shorter and longer tours) and it seemed just right.  The lobby has amazing mosaics and terracotta work, in addition to elevators designed by Tiffany.  Our guide was very knowledgeable about the history of the building and the team that built it, as well as its place in NYC history.  Highly recommend this tour!

data.title: Beautiful lobby
data.text: It's not your regular tourist attraction. You can't tour it, but do visit it next time in ny. It has a rich history, beautiful architecture and I especially love the lobby. The space in the lobby is limited but beautiful.

data.title: See this while you can.  It's beautiful and historic and the tour is great.
data.text: I took the 90 minute tour one beautiful afternoon in October.  So much history!! and the architecture and detail is astonishing.  It's an iconic building and I stepped in one day a few years ago and was promptly told to leave by the guards.  The ceilings alone are worth the tour.  Years later so happy they have tours now.  I was a bit disappointed we didn't see the pool, but the tour guide was exceptional and thorough.  You linger in the main lobby for much of the tour and you can't take your eyes off all the detail and the ceiling mosaics.  The tour gives you great history of the building, the Woolworth company, and the man who started it all.  Well worth the time and money.  If you like architecture or american history you will not be disappointed.

data.title: Wow
data.text:
What a beautiful lobby. Mr. Woolworth shared his wealth by giving New York City the tallest building in the world for a number of years. What a building it is.
    As a Woodworker by trade this lobby was a must see. There is so much to try and our tour guide was very informative. He shared a lot of personal experiences from years of guiding tours through the building. Our guide also had a lot of knowledge about many of the other buildings in the area.
   Well worth the money and time.

data.title: Don't miss touring this gem!
data.text: We did the 90 minute tour  I had always wanted to see the interior of this masterpiece and was not disappointed. Our guide was so knowledgeable, sharing facts in a really enjoyable way. The tour included the exterior, the pool and safe in the basement, the spectacular tile- ceilinged lobby (with a closeup as a bonus)  the identities of the sculpted busts throughout and so much more.

data.title: Worth a Look!
data.text:
My spouse and I took a tour of the Woolworth Building on a Saturday afternoon in mid-August 2016. We booked our tickets online, which is necessary because there is no ticket window, and you cannot walk in and pay on-the-spot. In fact, a sign in front of the building advises “No Tourists Allowed”, and a security officer seriously guards the door.

Several different architectural tours of the building’s magnificent vintage lobby are available: a 30-minute tour, a 60-minute tour, and a 90-minute tour. We chose the longest tour so that we would have maximum access to the public areas of the building, and the time passed quickly. We were fortunate to tour as part of a small group, just ourselves and two other guests, plus the guide. As directed on the confirmation email, we met our guide outside the front entrance to the building at 233 Broadway (near Park Place). There are no public restroom facilities available; in fact, we tried to use the facilities at the Starbucks in the same block, and we were turned away (which we thought was against Starbucks policy). Tours include stairs and significant time standing. No seating is available, but you may bring your own folding chair if necessary. Questions are welcomed and flash-less still photography is permitted. Children under 10 are not allowed, and food, drinks, and pets are prohibited. Tours are held rain or shine, because they occur primarily inside. 

In 1913, Frank W. Woolworth (owner of the five-and-ten cents stores), commissioned architect Cass Gilbert to design the building as his NYC headquarters. (Gilbert also designed other buildings in Lower Manhattan, including the Custom House, Broadway Chambers Building, and West Street Building, as well as the United States Supreme Court in DC). The landmark Woolworth Building remained the tallest skyscraper in the world for the next 17 years. Critics applauded Gilbert’s design because it created a picturesque Gothic silhouette in skyline views. Its commanding central tower featured soaring verticals. The tower’s upper stages, evocative of European cathedrals, contained gables, turrets (tourelles), hook-shaped elements (crockets), and decorative ornaments (finials). At the building’s base, a Tudor Gothic portal opened to a monumental lobby remininscent of a Romanesque cathedral nave. Vaults covered with Byzantine mosaics, gilded cornices, and murals of labor and commerce framing a gracious marble staircase leads to the now-defunct Irving National Bank. The building features an extensive exterior terracotta cladding system.

In its heyday, the building offered its tenants luxurious office space, a shopping arcade, health club (with swimming pool), subway station, and a medieval German Rathskeller, as well as high-speed elevators, self-sustaining electrical power generation, heating, cooling, water supply, and fire protection. Throughout the 1920s and 1930s, the tower’s pinnacle observatory served as one of the city’s leading tourist attractions. Visitors from around the world enjoyed a thrilling panorama of lower Manhattan and beyond. The Woolworth Building was named a National Historic Landmark in 1966 and a New York City Landmark in 1983. It currently houses both commercial and residential tenants.

During the vibrant economy of the 1920s, Gilbert’s skyscraper Gothic design was viewed at home and abroad as a symbol of American material success. To this day, it evokes the mood of the early 20th century, when New York served as the country’s most prosperous port and gateway for the commerce to the world.

Our tour guide, Lisa Renz, is a preservationist and architectural historian who specializes in 19th and 20th century American architecture. Lisa holds a BA in Architectural History and Theory from Columbia University and an MS in Historic Preservation from Columbia University. She has been researching the Woolworth Building primarily through extensive study of the physical building itself and the archives of Woolworth architect Cass Gilbert through the New York Historical Society. Born and raised in Minneapolis, MN, Lisa has lived in New York City since 2001. She works full-time for a General Contractor as their Historic Preservationist and Project/Site Manager and is currently working on the restoration of Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights.

After you have visited all the major must-see sites in NYC, make time in your itinerary to visit the gorgeous Woolworth Building!

data.title: Great iconic building
data.text: A pity the security gurads wont let you in the entrance - dash in and grab a quick photo before tehy ask you to leave its well worth the effort for a truly art deco lobby
